title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for inspection. Section 7 outlines the information needed in the registration statement. The Securities Act of 1933 requires registration of securities with the SEC before public offering. The registration statement includes details like underwriters, business type, shareholders, debt, assets, and legal opinions. Section 10(a) specifies prospectus information, with additional regulations from the commission. Exempt transactions include private placements, intrastate offerings, and certain securities like government and bank securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 covers various areas. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires registration for issuers with securities traded on a national exchange or with total assets exceeding $10,000,000 and a certain number of shareholders. Issuers must file periodic reports with the SEC, including detailed statements upon registration and annual/quarterly reports. Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 mandates registered companies to submit annual and quarterly reports to the SEC, containing all material information necessary for investors. Section 14 covers proxy solicitation, with exemptions available. Failure to disclose material information is legally actionable under Section 18(a), providing investors with a private right of action for reliance on misstatements or omissions in SEC filings. Regulations specify the required information in these reports. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires investment companies to register with the SEC and disclose specified information to protect investors. Non-compliance restricts participation in certain securities activities. Directors, officers, and employees must disclose affiliations and interests. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 regulates investment advisers who provide advice on securities for compensation. They must register with the SEC and comply with reporting requirements. Unauthorized advisers cannot use interstate commerce for their business. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 increases sanctions against insider trading to deter violations. Insider trading involves trading securities with material nonpublic information. This act aims to maintain fair and honest securities markets. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-704) allows the SEC to penalize individuals who engage in insider trading with civil penalties up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided. It also increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations, established a bounty program for informants, and required broker-dealers and investment advisers to take steps to prevent insider trading. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 addressed frivolous shareholder lawsuits due to fraud, mismanagement, and nondisclosure of material information, leading to shareholder losses. Some lawsuits were valid, alleging corporate managers misled or defrauded investors, while others were deemed frivolous. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to limit shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, and requiring auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. It was a response to perceived failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing alleged abuses of securities fraud litigation. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to address the perceived shortcomings of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in controlling securities fraud litigation. SLUSA aimed to prevent plaintiffs from bypassing PSLRA requirements by mandating that securities fraud cases be filed only in federal courts under specific criteria. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom. It established a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, restricted accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit, and required additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. The act also addresses securities fraud and internal management controls. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 addressed issues for public companies and their officers, including securities fraud, management controls, penalties for violating laws, insider trading restrictions, and whistleblower protections. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial crisis, made significant changes to financial regulation, particularly affecting the securities industry through Title VII which regulates the over-the-counter swaps markets and outlines jurisdictional parameters for regulatory agencies. Title IX of the Dodd-Frank Act enhances SEC powers by creating an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower program for securities fraud disclosures. It also includes provisions to increase investor protection, such as regulating credit rating agencies and requiring shareholder votes on executive compensation packages. The Dodd-Frank Act includes provisions for shareholder votes on executive compensation packages and regulations on insider trading by Members of Congress and congressional employees. It also establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and requires disclosure of minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting armed groups. The STOCK Act prohibits insider trading by Members of Congress and congressional employees, affirming a duty of trust and confidence. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements to encourage funding for small businesses and startups, with Title I for emerging growth companies and Title III for crowdfunding being notable. Emerging growth companies with annual revenues under $1 billion can phase in SEC regulations and submit draft registration statements confidentially. Title III exempts certain companies from the 1933 Securities Act's registration requirements. Title III of the JOBS Act exempts certain companies from the 1933 Securities Act's registration requirements if specific conditions are met, such as limits on the amount of securities sold to investors and the requirement to sell transactions through a funding portal.
